title: Will there still be dictionaries in 2020?

author: Magali Paquot, Institut Langage et Communication, Université catholique de Louvain

segmentation: I am the last speaker of this roundtable.
I'd like to end with a more optimistic statement.
My point is that the Internet as maids, dictionaries, trendy are.
Whenever.
Perhaps there have never been as many dictionary users as today and online dictionaries are probably being consulted by knew types of users.

For example, two of the most consulted on line dictionarysothatsthefreedictionary.com anwordreference.com attract roughly the same amount, the same number of daily unique visitors as British online newspaper, such as the Guardian which offers.
Knew an free content every day.
More Interestingly
Perhaps the French Journal of July.
Jeanette recently published a list of websites that attracted the highest number of social actions from Facebook members.
Three types of social actions were measured on Facebook the likes.
When Facebook members click on the like button on a particular website, the like button let's users share a website with their friends friends on Facebook at the comments.

All Facebook comments that include the URL of a particular website and the shares, so that's where when Facebook members click on the share button on a particular website and actually word reference is the third most social world domain name on Facebook.
Just after youtube.com and vimeo.com.
So two websites for sharing sound files and videos, word references.
Well, it's the only dictionary that appears in this top 100 list.

Of most sociable domain names, but it has been the object of many more social actions than Twitter and other web to web sites, for example as well as established news media such as New York Times that come.
Comments on wordreference.com are all very positive word reference rocks.
It is the most complete multilingual dictionary online and I also found found quite a number of comments made by professional translators.
We report extensive use of red reference and consider the tool as a very useful resource for their daily work.
So I was wondering what?
What are the characteristics of word reference?
First, it is a dictionary portal that provides access to multi functional, monolingual and bilingual dictionaries as shown by the Selena at the 14th year.
Like in your Alexa International Congress in 2010, users are searching for bilingual dictionary content.
Online dictionary users are also searching for phrases.
The lexicographical treatment of phrases.
Another phraseological units.

In traditional paper like bilingual dictionaries, is still far from satisfactory and clearly lacks behind corpus driven developments witnessed in monolingual dictionaries and more particularly learner's dictionaries.
Wordreference.com builds on its users to compile a collaborative Dictionary of compound forms.
Users can also ask questions related to the translation.
Of particular phrases in dedicated language bears, foreheads, and these questions, together with their answers are fed into growing database of translation equivalence across languages.
So the word reference model does not make use of any inovative NLP feature.
In fact, the most widely used online dictionaries are not NLP informed.
They are rather models of Web 2 success stories.
In the new making and doing culture paradigm that according to godly 2011, now characterizes modern modern societies.
One of the.

Central ideas of today's roundtable is that if the field of NLP keeps on progressing in addressing major challenges such as word sense, disambiguation of machine translation, knew applications and tools will perhaps end up performing the same function as dictionaries with exampleofwordreference.com.
We've seen that this is still very far from the truth.
I'd like to argue that perhaps the role of MLP.
In shaping future electronic dictionaries is only if I may say so of interest to researchers and more particularly, publishers and editors.
As Michael explains, old school dictionaries publishers need to invent new revenue stream and perhaps also cuts the costs.
Recent developments in monolingual learners dictionaries .2 publishers need to offer new features at reduced costs in the Longman Dictionary for Contemporary.

English, for example, a number of collocations and example sentences where automatically extracted from the corpus and they do not seem to have been validated, which is, I think a bit worrying for such a prestigious dictionary, to say the least.

My point here is that publishers seem to be thinking of natural language processing as a way of cutting the costs by providing automatically derived lexicographical information at a time when they should invest.
Massively in research and development in LMP if they really think that NLP can help them cut the costs.
We are still very far from the degree of accuracy that would be desirable in any respectable dictionary.
And here I see many opportunities for collaboration between universities and publishers.
In the meantime, I think that dictionaries Everbrite online future the Internet as opens up unprecedented opportunities for collaborative lexicography.
Collaborative lexicography has the potential of improving dictionaries, for example, by increasing their coverage and lexicographical treatment of phraseology.
As we've seen with thewordreference.com example, however, collaborative lexicography.

The Wiktionary project for example may also looks disappointedly old-fashioned, collaborative lexicography on the other hands, also provides a unique opportunity for lesser, lesser resource languages asked by Prince Low.
In a forthcoming article on electronic lexicography for South African languages, the electronic era don't appan Bantu languages.
Lexicography at a time when the goal of compiling.
A good dictionaries for these languages have not yet been attained, so dictionaries such as easyzulu.net welcome users contributions in a dedicated forum.
These contributions are used to increase the dictionaries lexical coverage and add new Zulu English translations.
Um research lead dictionaries, as well as also increase their visibility enormously thanks to the Internet medium.
The dictionaries listed on this slide are just a couple of examples, but there are many, many more.
Some of these dictionaries, for example transfer ticker innovate by incorporating aspects of the two paradigms.
So the MLP based lexicography versus the user generated content lexicography, an it is expected that we will see.

More dictionaries of this type in the future and we had a very good example yesterday with Wordnik, now with all these dictionaries, pure players, dictionaries, collaborative dictionaries, research lab dictionaries will all these dictionaries be used and how?
We definitely need more dictionaries, dictionary use research to inform our practices.
At some point, the final say will go to the dictionary users.
The problem is that we know very little about them.
We need more studies of that.
I presented by Carolyn Bruno Spitzer and her colleagues yesterday afternoon, but we also need these studies to find a way to fish out all these mainstream users.
Users were not linguists were not translators, but would click the like button when they navigate a dictionary website suchaswordreference.com.
So this probably means that we need to contact mainstream dictionary users through their usual communications channels, that is via Facebook and Twitter for example.
So to conclude, I think that today.
May not be a great time for dictionary publishers, but it is a very exciting time for lexicography.
Thank you.
Play.
